metadata.synopsis: In Wes Craven's classic slasher film, several Midwestern teenagers fall prey to Freddy Krueger (Robert Englund), a disfigured midnight mangler who preys on the teenagers in their dreams -- which, in turn, kills them in reality. After investigating the phenomenon, Nancy (Heather Langenkamp) begins to suspect that a dark secret kept by her and her friends' parents may be the key to unraveling the mystery, but can Nancy and her boyfriend Glen (Johnny Depp) solve the puzzle before it's too late?

reviews: Can we go to sleep? Is it safe? When filmmakers attack real life phobias and security blankets, horror films hit a peak high.
Krueger's makeup is still awe-inspiring and the onslaught of innovative ideas are sinisterly unique.
A senseless yet intriguing splatter horror film that was well-received by the public.
The beginning of Freddy is as solid as it was decades ago. This still makes us scared to fall asleep. [Full review in Spanish]
What makes the movie work is so simple and economical-you snooze, you die. I've always admired its simplicity.
Great build-up, the suspense and apprehension, getting you invested in a sequence...this movie has that.
The script is consistently witty, the camera work (by cinematographer Jacques Haitkin) crisp and expressive.
Not since the shower scene in Psycho did one director discover our most intimate vulnerabilities: in bed, while we're asleep, in a state of consciousness where absolutely no one could help us.
A smart, streamlined slasher with plenty under the bonnet.
A top-flight terror classic that spawned seven sequels and a TV series.
Craven knows which big, red Freudian buttons to push, turning Freddy into a true monster from the Id.
First feature for knife-handed horror idol Freddy.
...a low-key horror effort that's ultimately not quite as enthralling as its premise might've indicated...
An imaginative, menacing, and scary film with top notch performances, an original premise, and horrifying villain...

Seeing the movie again, I was reminded that while the Krueger character did have some taunting, humorous dialogue, it was more eerie than funny. Krueger was truly a menacing, terrifying boogeyman in the beginning.
... ingenious exploitation that plays on primal fears and subconscious anxieties...
...decidedly anti-art - at one point, a teen dozes off while reading Shakespeare - yet it still manages to rank among the top horror movies of all time.
A fantastic horror film that still holds up resoundingly well today.
What the film did more than anything else was create a new horror star.
The Sandman of Reagan's dozy suburbia
